vague_description: Determining the optimal allocation of resources for maximizing daily customer interactions while adhering to employee limitations.
detailed_description: A clothing company can sell their product in two types of stores, a retail store and a factory outlet. A retail store brings in \param{RetailCustomers} customers every day and requires \param{RetailEmployees} employees to operate. A factory outlet brings in \param{OutletCustomers} customers every day and due to the lower traffic and being in more remote areas, requires \param{OutletEmployees} employees to run. Company executives decided that there must be at least \param{MinCustomers} customers every day, and can make available \param{TotalEmployees} employees. How should the company distribute their product to the two types of store to reduce the number of stores that must be open?
target_objective: Minimize the number of stores (retail stores and factory outlets) that must be open
target_constraints: Number of retail stores is non-negative
Number of factory outlets is non-negative
Total number of customers from retail stores and factory outlets must be at least MinCustomers
Total number of employees distributed to all stores cannot exceed TotalEmployees
Each retail store requires RetailEmployees employees to operate
Each factory outlet requires OutletEmployees employees to run
target_parameters: Number of customers a retail store brings in every day
Number of customers a factory outlet brings in every day
Number of employees required to operate a retail store
Number of employees required to operate a factory outlet
Minimum required number of customers every day
Total number of employees available to operate all stores
